item.title: Volkswagen Suffers More Than Rivals From Auto Industry Woes
item.description: The German automaker’s sales in the United States plunged last year, hit by tariffs and the end of tax credits for electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.category: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks
item.media:credit: Jens Schlueter/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Electric vehicles at a Volkswagen plant in Dresden, Germany. The company is an extreme example of how difficult it has been for foreign automakers to cope in the U.S. car market.

item.title: Judge Bars Trump From Withholding Election Funds to States
item.description: The ruling is the latest legal setback to President Trump’s sweeping effort to compel changes to state election standards.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Nick Hagen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Voters last year in Dearborn, Mich. “The Constitution assigns no authority to the president over federal election administration,” the judge wrote in his ruling.

item.title: Trump Calls for 10 Percent Credit Card Interest Cap, After Killing Other Fee Limits
item.description: The president revived a campaign promise he has not actively pursued since taking office.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Russell Vought, CFPB Leader, Requests $145 Million for Agency He Wants to Eliminate
item.description: A federal judge ordered Russell T. Vought, the bureau’s acting director, to keep requesting funds for the financial watchdog’s operations.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Russell T. Vought, the acting director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, outside the White House in September.

item.title: Trump Administration Freezes Food Stamps in Minnesota
item.description: The move was part of a broader effort to to freeze social services to some Democratic-led states amid a fraud investigation in Minnesota.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A food pantry in Minnesota last year.

item.title: Dr. Oz Visits California to Target ‘Fraud’
item.description: Dr. Mehmet Oz, the head of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid, and Bill Essayli, a Los Angeles-based prosecutor, said they were investigating federally funded services.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Dr. Mehmet Oz, the administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid, left, and Bill Essayli, the first assistant U.S. attorney for the Central District of California, said they would ramp up efforts to detect fraud in government programs.

item.title: Judge Blocks Trump Officials From Freezing Billions in Social Services Funds
item.description: The ruling temporarily halted plans to freeze more than $10 billion in funds for anti-poverty programs bound for five Democratic-led states.
item.dc:creator: Zach Montague and Minho Kim
item.media:credit: Mark Vancleave/Associated Press
item.media:description: Children watching television at ABC Learning Center in Minneapolis in December. Minnesota is one of the states that was targeted for a freeze in child care subsidies and other funds.

item.title: Gavin Newsom on Democrats, 2028 and His Fruit-Only Breakfasts
item.description: The California governor is powered by smoothies and bursting with thoughts about U.S. politics.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gavin Newsom

item.title: Trump Threatens to Take Greenland ‘the Hard Way’
item.description: The president continued to advance an imperialist vision of American foreign policy, where the U.S. can dominate neighboring countries “whether they like it or not.”
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and members of his cabinet at the meeting with oil executives at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Washington National Opera Is Leaving the Kennedy Center
item.description: The opera, which has performed at the arts center since 1971, was concerned about declines in attendance and donations during President Trump’s second term.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Washington National Opera officials contend that exiting the Kennedy Center would also give it more control over programming decisions.

item.title: Trump’s $100 Billion Venezuela Oil Plan Gets a Cool Reception
item.description: President Trump met with oil and gas executives on Friday in an effort to push them to invest money in Venezuela, a plan many of them are reluctant to embrace.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump during a meeting with energy executives at the White House on Friday. He wants the biggest U.S. and European oil companies to pour at least $100 billion into Venezuela.

item.title: What Is the War Powers Resolution, and Why Is Trump’s Claim About It Misleading?
item.description: The resolution created different sections of statutory code. A part the Senate is weighing using has not been widely seen as unconstitutional.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: The War Powers Resolution is a set of statutes Congress enacted in 1974 — and tweaked in 1983 — in an effort to reclaim its constitutionally intended role of deciding if the United States would go to war.

item.title: Christopher Raia to Be FBI Deputy Director After Bongino’s Departure
item.description: Even as the selection of a career agent, Christopher G. Raia, leaves an unusual three-person leadership structure in place, it returns a career agent to the No. 2 post.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett, William K. Rashbaum and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Adam Gray for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christopher G. Raia was a Coast Guard officer before he joined the F.B.I. As an agent, he spent much of his career in Texas, rising through the ranks from investigating violent crime to managing counterterrorism work.

item.title: Jobs Report Shows U.S. Hiring Slowed One Year Into Trump’s Second Term
item.description: As economists pointed to some of the president’s policies to explain the latest Labor Department data, White House aides sought to make the case for optimism in the new year.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Ben Casselman
item.category: White House Council of Economic Advisers
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: The December jobs tally showed how President Trump’s agenda may have impacted the economy during his first year back in office.

item.title: GOP Seeks Some Distance From Trump as Midterm Election Year Opens
item.description: The vote to open a war powers debate, a pair of attempted veto overrides and a split on health care suggested a greater appetite among Republicans to challenge the president.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times

item.title: Trump Officials Reopen Thousands of Refugee Claims in Minnesota
item.description: The review comes as the federal government escalates its immigration enforcement in the state.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Somali community in Minnesota, the largest in the country, has been the target of increased immigration enforcement.

item.title: How Our White House Photographer Finds New Angles on the Oval Office
item.description: Doug Mills, winner of three Pulitzers, sits, crawls and hoists cameras high in the air to bring viewers fresh perspectives. He was at it again this week during our marathon interview with President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Jodi Rudoren and Doug Mills
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Doug Mills, left, photographing President Trump after an interview with The New York Times on Wednesday.

item.title: Supreme Court Issues First Ruling of Term but Don’t Yet Get To Tariffs
item.description: Only once in the modern era have the justices taken this long to issue their first decision — and when it came, it wasn’t the hotly anticipated case on President Trump’s tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Over the last 80 years, the Supreme Court has only once before waited until January to issue its first opinion in an argued case.

item.title: U.S. Boards Another Tanker Carrying Venezuelan Oil
item.description: The tanker, the Olina, is the fifth to be boarded or seized by U.S. forces in recent weeks as part of an effort to control Venezuela’s oil exports.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert, Eric Schmitt and Nicholas Nehamas
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Maryorin Mendez/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Silhouettes of children carrying a net at a fishing pier while in the background a crude oil tanker is docking in Venezuela’s Maracaibo Lake on Thursday.

item.title: Why Many Republican Voters Support Trump’s Use of Force in Venezuela
item.description: They don’t like nation building, but they do want to project American power.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s raid has been viewed with measured skepticism by some influential supporters, who disdain interventions abroad.

item.title: Brian Heywood Is Bankrolling Conservative Ballot Measures in Washington
item.description: Brian Heywood, a Seattle-area hedge fund founder, has spent millions to put conservative initiatives in front of Washington lawmakers and voters. Next up: parental rights and transgender athletes.
item.dc:creator: Anna Griffin
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: “My intention with the initiatives always is to do as little intrusive damage as possible,” said Brian Heywood, a hedge fund founder using his wealth to bankroll ballot initiatives.

item.title: Wary of Investing in Venezuela, Big Oil Heads to the White House
item.description: The amounts of money, time and political uncertainty trouble executives at large Western oil companies, who plan to meet with President Trump on Friday.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue near the Venezuelan state oil company in Caracas. U.S. energy executives were far from ready to make a commitment when President Trump said they would “spend billions of dollars” in that country.

item.title: How Americans Learned to Love Thomas Paine
item.description: His “Common Sense,” published 250 years ago, ignited the drive for American independence. That was hardly the end of the radical founder’s strange and winding story.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Tony Cenicola/The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas Paine, whose 1776 pamphlet “Common Sense” helped spark the American Revolution, was hailed by some as the greatest radical of the age and reviled by others as a rabble-rousing atheist.
